Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal supports the Connections in Smart Health 2018: Principal Investigators Workshop in Arlington, VA on September 24-26, 2018. The meeting will bring together principal investigators of projects awarded by the Smart and Connected Health program from with other researchers looking at smart health in the broader community. The SCH program was set up in order to bridge gaps in fundamental science necessary to transform health and healthcare, as well as to be focused on prevention and person-centered care. Connections in Smart Health Workshop is designed to address the next generation of challenges in advancing health with foundational research from the computer science, engineering and the social, behavioral and economic disciplines. An objective of the Workshop is to provide an opportunity for the principal investigators and other smart health researchers to explore research progress in a diverse set of projects and discuss important current issues, as well as future challenges associated with research in transdisciplinary scientific areas. The discussions will be supported by keynotes, panels, project-related posters, rapid talks and participant-generated workshops. It is anticipated that the meeting will stimulate discussions, connections, and collaborations that will facilitate progress in the area of Smart and Connected Health.

The workshop should have a significant impact on the participants and the future of the Smart and Connected Health program. The focus of the workshop is on foundational research that supports the growth of smart health within connected communities. The workshop results are likely to include new research directions that will be publicized to the research community through publications and a workshop website. The results dissemination should inform and the developing Smart and Connected Health research community in their transdisciplinary collaboration, educational activities, and spur other innovative research directions. The broader impacts of the workshop are to facilitate progress in the field and stimulate conversations, connections, and collaborations that will lead toward better informed and effective smart and connected health research and resulting technologies for the broadest possible user populations. Additionally, there will be a workshop attached to the Principal Investigator meeting that will support the travel for ten students from under-represented STEM disciplines to attend the PI Workshop. This should also help grow the field by providing mentorship and support for a new cadre of investigators looking to do work in the Smart and Connected Health area.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2018 Connections in Smart Health workshop was held September 23-26, 2018 at the Renaissance Arlington Capital View Hotel in Arlington, VA. The workshop served as a Smart and Connected Health (SCH) Principle Investigator (PI) meeting, a broadening participation in computing (BPC) workshop for smart health, and a smart health visioning workshop. As the purpose of the SCH program is to encourage research communities to come together to explore new opportunities and directions for next generation solutions to enhance health, this workshop included SCH PIs, aspiring PIs, PhD students studying smart health, and other leaders in the research community. In total, there were 249 attendees, including 140 SCH PIs, 76 invited participants, 16 government agency representatives, 10 student travel awardees, and 7 support staff.

The first goal of the workshop was to discuss and promote advances in smart health research. Since this workshop served as the SCH PI meeting, it brought together 140 PIs of current SCH-funded projects, and every project had both a lightning talk and a poster, showcasing the recent and ongoing advances in the field. In addition, there were two expert panels on "Virtual, Augmented and Mixed Reality to Support Smart Health" and "Advanced Analytics for Health: Hype or Hero?", there were six parallel 1.75 hour birds-of-a-feather breakouts, and there were eight parallel 2.25 hour mini-workshops.

The second goal was to foster partnerships for the future of smart health. In addition to the new partnerships that commonly form among existing PIs at a PI meeting, this workshop sought to grow the community and enable a more diverse set of possible partnerships. As such, applications were solicited from non-SCH-funded researchers, including academics and government and industry leaders who were interested in engaging with the smart health research community to shape the future of the field. 143 researchers applied, and 76 were selected to attend. All gave lightning talks and presented a poster, stimulating significant new connections. The workshop also had a government panel on "Federal Funding for Smart Health", and representatives from major health resource centers participated on an expert panel and ran workshops on Day 3.

The third goal was to help develop the future of smart health through aspiring PI and student mentoring, including BPC outreach. There were numerous aspiring PIs among the 76 non-SCH-funded researches, and a 1.75 hour aspiring PI workshop was held on Day 1. The workshop also released a call for applications from current PhD students studying smart health. 33 students from 28 different universities applied, and 10 were selected to attend, including 9 women and 1 African American male. They all presented a lightning talk and a poster and fully participated in the entire workshop. In addition, they attended a student/mentor dinner on Day 1 that included 9 faculty mentors, where each student gave a brief pitch on their work and were able to ask questions about their career development as smart health researchers.

Based on the post-workshop survey results, it is clear that the three goals were effectively met. 80 surveys were received, and most of the feedback was extremely positive. Some highlights:

  • In response to the question "Overall, did you find the Connections in Smart Health Workshop to be useful?", on a 1-5 Likert scale of "Not Useful" to "Very Useful", 56 gave a 5, 22 gave a 4, and 1 gave a 3. No 2's or 1's were received.
  • In response to the question "Did you make new connections at the meeting?", 75/80 replied "yes".
  • Of the 48 respondents who attended the aspiring PI workshop, 45 indicated that it was "Very Useful" or "Somewhat Useful".
  • The most popular part of the program was the lightning talks, with 75/80 respondents indicating that they were "Very Useful" or "Somewhat Useful".

Intellectual Merit: This meeting brought together experts from different disciplines that comprise smart health. The workshop identified gaps, needs, resources, and barriers in community collaborations, stimulated and promoted new partnerships, and assessed future actions for the program.

Broader Impacts: The purpose of the research from the smart health community is to produce innovations in fundamental science that enable improvements in health and quality of life. The workshop provided researchers with new directions and new connections to both explore next generation smart health solutions and to further grow and empower the smart health community.
